metadata.parsed_text_markdown:
# Overview 2023

The figure includes the first residence permits issued by the Finnish Immigration Service to third-country nationals as well as the registration of the right of residence of EU citizens and their family members. It also includes the beneficiaries of temporary protection.

In 2023, the largest group was third-country nationals who entered the country on the grounds of family ties. The second largest group was people who had fled the war in Ukraine and were granted temporary protection.

| Category | Number |
|----------|--------|
| Employment | 15,081 |
| Family | 20,278 |
| International protection | 1,370 |
| Temporary protection | 18,969 |
| Registrations of EU citizens | 8,479 |
| Refugee quota | 1,050 |
| Study | 12,795 |
| Other* | 955 |
| **Total** | **78,977** |

*Also includes residence permits issued on other grounds in the asylum process

Source: Finnish Immigration Service

__data__.text:
The Overview 2023 section presents key statistics on residence permits issued in Finland, highlighting that a total of 78,977 permits were granted, with the largest group being third-country nationals entering on family ties (20,278) and those receiving temporary protection due to the war in Ukraine (18,969). This data is part of a broader analysis of immigration trends in Finland for 2023, reflecting the impact of ongoing global conflicts and migration patterns, as detailed throughout the document.

# Work in Finland

In 2023, a total of 15,081 first residence permits were issued on the grounds of employment, showing a slight decrease from the previous year but remaining high in historical comparison. The number has been showing an upward trend, with the exception of the year 2020 when the COVID-19 pandemic caused a temporary drop in the numbers.

## First residence permits and extended permits issued on the grounds of employment, 2019-2023

| Year | First residence permits on the grounds of employment | Extended permits on the grounds of employment |
|------|------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|
| 2019 | 8,255                                                | 9,461                                         |
| 2020 | 8,508                                                | 10,461                                        |
| 2021 | 11,428                                               | 12,992                                        |
| 2022 | 16,081                                               | 12,374                                        |
| 2023 | 15,081                                               | 19,476                                        |

## Gender distribution, first residence permits issued 2023

| Gender | Percentage |
|--------|------------|
| Men    | 68%        |
| Women  | 32%        |

Additionally, the gender distribution indicates that 68% of the permits were issued to men, underscoring the demographic trends in the labor migration landscape within the broader context of immigration statistics for Finland in 2023.

metadata.parsed_text_markdown:
# Migration to Finland on the grounds of family ties

In 2023, the most common grounds for issuing a residence permit were family ties. A total of 20,278 applicants were issued a first residence permit on the basis of family ties by the Finnish Immigration Service, a considerable increase from the previous year (2022: 15,457).

Of these, 3,308 were applicants considered to be family members of Finnish citizens. A total of 1,731 residence permits were issued to family members of beneficiaries of international protection. Similarly to the previous year, the most common categories by far were spouse of a third-country national (7,119) and child of other third-country national (8,076).

Pursuant to the Aliens Act, family members of foreign nationals living in Finland and Finnish citizens are:

- spouse
- registered partner
- cohabitation partner (a requirement of living together for two years unless the couple has a child in joint custody)
- unmarried child under 18 years of age under the care and custody of the person living in Finland
- guardian, if the person living in Finland is under 18 years old.

The statistics on residence permit applications on the grounds of family ties also include applicants outside the nuclear family, other relatives, for example the parents and siblings of an adult.

__data__.text:
The chunk focuses on the issuance of residence permits in Finland based on family ties, highlighting that 20,278 permits were granted in 2023, a significant increase from 15,457 in 2022. It details the composition of these permits, noting that 7,119 were issued to spouses and 8,076 to children of third-country nationals, while also outlining the definitions of family members under the Aliens Act. This information is part of a broader statistical review of immigration trends in Finland for 2023, which includes various grounds for migration and reflects the increasing importance of family reunification in the immigration process.

# Migration to Finland on the grounds of studying

Residence permits for studies were issued to 12,795 third-country nationals in 2023. This represents a substantial increase compared to 2022 (8,383) and a leap over the previous years' level. The decline in 2020 was mainly due to the COVID-19 pandemic. A total of 495 applicants (approx. 4%) received a negative decision on their application for a first residence permit for studies. A negative decision usually results from irregularities concerning subsistence.

The top nationalities in residence permits issued on the grounds of studying were Bangladesh (1,579), Sri Lanka (1,261) and China (1,233).

# Registration of the right of residence of an EU citizen and family members

The Finnish Immigration Service registers the right of residence of EU citizens and issues residence cards to the family members of EU citizens. A residence card is issued to an EU citizen's family member who is not an EU citizen. The number of registrations of rights of residence of EU citizens in 2023 continued a slight decline from the previous years. The largest group for whom registrations were performed in 2023 was, as in the previous years, Estonians (1,492).

metadata.parsed_text_markdown:
# Permanent residence permit

A permanent residence permit is valid until further notice. In other words, its validity is not limited. A permanent residence permit may be issued when the person has resided in Finland continuously for four years on a continuous residence permit and the conditions for issuing a continuous residence permit are still met. The EU residence permit of a long-term resident from a third country is also considered a permanent residence permit. This requires five years of continuous residence in Finland and it also entitles the holder to stay in another Schengen country for at most 90 days.

# How many people sought asylum in Finland?

A total of 5,372 persons applied for international protection in Finland in 2023. Of these, 348 were asylum-seeking unaccompanied minors. Of the asylum applications, 15% (813) were subsequent applications. A subsequent application is an application for international protection filed by a foreign national after receiving a final decision on a previously submitted application. The share of subsequent applications in all asylum applications showed an increase in the previous years, but the trend has been declining over the past five years.

## First applications and subsequent applications, 2019-2023

| Year | First applications | Subsequent applications | Total |
|------|--------------------|-----------------------|-------|
| 2019 | 2,532              | 2,018                 | 4,550 |
| 2020 | 1,932              | 1,277                 | 3,209 |
| 2021 | 1,379              | 1,166                 | 2,545 |
| 2022 | 4,941              | 886                   | 5,827 |
| 2023 | 4,559              | 813                   | 5,372 |

## Gender distribution, applications, 2023

| Gender | Percentage |
|--------|------------|
| Men    | 69%        |
| Women  | 31%        |

# Who were the asylum-seeking unaccompanied minors?

The term "asylum-seeking unaccompanied minor" refers to a person who states that he/she is under 18 years of age and who enters the country either completely alone or with a person who is not his/her parent or guardian (or sufficient evidence of guardianship of the said person is not provided) in order to seek asylum.

A total of 348 unaccompanied minor asylum seekers entered Finland in 2023. This showed a clear increase from the previous year (246) and presented a continuation of the rising trend. In addition, 188 unaccompanied minors fled Russia's war of aggression from Ukraine to Finland and applied for temporary protection in Finland.

The countries of origin with the most unaccompanied minor asylum seekers entering Finland were Somalia (179), Afghanistan (54) and Syria (25).

The Finnish Immigration Service made 3,586 asylum decisions in 2023. Positive asylum decisions accounted for 43% of all decisions in the asylum process. The share of negative decisions of all decisions was about 21%. The number of decisions to dismiss the application (including Dublin decisions) was 673 (19%). The number of expired applications was 590 (approx. 17% of all decisions).

metadata.parsed_text_markdown:
# Temporary protection

A total of 19,426 applications for temporary protection were lodged in Finland in 2023, less than half of the corresponding figure in 2022 (47,302). The number of decisions made was 19,936, of which 18,969 were positive. Ukrainians accounted for 97% of the applications and 98% of the decisions, but there were other nationalities as well.

The number of applications remained quite steady throughout the year, but showed a downward trend. In November and December, fewer than a thousand applications per month were lodged, the lowest numbers since Russia's war of aggression started. In early summer, there was an increase in the number of application due to the seasonal workers who arrived in Finland.

## Focusing on temporary protection

In 2022, millions of people sought shelter in the EU and its neighbouring countries due to Russian's military attack on Ukraine that started on 24 February 2022. As a result, the EU activated the Temporary Protection Directive on 4 March 2022. The Directive was originally approved in 2001 after the armed conflicts in the Western Balkans had caused large-scale forced migration in Europe, to EU Member States, for example.

Temporary protection is the EU's emergency mechanism, which is activated in cases of exceptional mass influx. The mechanism offers collective protection to displaced persons. This separate protection category also reduces the pressure on the EU Member States' national asylum systems. On 28 September 2023, the Council of the European Union decided to extend temporary protection until 4 March 2025.

Temporary protection may only be granted to

- Ukrainian citizens unable to return to Ukraine due to Russia's invasion
- citizens of countries outside the European Union and not party to the Schengen Agreement and stateless persons who have legally resided in Ukraine and whose safe and permanent return to their country of origin is not possible
- family members of Ukrainian citizens and of those granted interna-

This information is part of a broader statistical review on immigration in Finland for 2023, detailing various aspects of migration and asylum processes.

metadata.parsed_text_markdown:
# Quota refugees

Under the refugee quota, Finland accepts persons whom the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) has designated as refugees or other foreign nationals who are in need of international protection.

Starting from 2001, the number of quota refugees accepted in Finland was 750 persons per year. However, in 2014 and 2015, an additional quota of 300 people was agreed on due to the crisis in Syria. The quota for 2016, 2017 and 2018 was again set at 750 persons but, in 2021, it was increased to 1,050 persons and in 2022, to 1,500 persons. In 2023, the quota was decreased to 1,050 persons.

In 2023, a total of 1,342 positive quota selection decisions were made. Of these, 293 were part of the quota for 2022.

## Allocation of the refugee quota, 2023

| Country                                | Number of Refugees |
|---------------------------------------|-------------------|
| Afghanistan                            | 503               |
| Syria                                  | 423               |
| Democratic Republic of the Congo       | 161               |
| Emergencies (various nationalities)    | 129               |
| Sudan                                  | 66                |
| Eritrea                                | 57                |
| Ethiopia                               | 2                 |
| South Sudan                            | 1                 |

__data__.text:
The chunk focuses on Finland's quota refugee program, detailing the annual acceptance of refugees designated by the UNHCR, with a historical overview of quota changes from 2001 to 2023. In 2023, the quota was set at 1,050 refugees, with 1,342 positive selection decisions made, including 293 from the previous year's quota. The allocation highlights significant numbers from countries such as Afghanistan (503) and Syria (423), reflecting Finland's ongoing commitment to international protection amidst broader immigration trends discussed throughout the document.

metadata.parsed_text_markdown:
# Reception of asylum seekers

The reception capacity of Finland has been continuously adjusted and the number of reception facilities had been reduced year by year compared to the situation at the end of 2015. However, there was a sharp uptick in the number of customers in 2022 due to the war in Ukraine, which required a fast capacity increase, resulting in a large number of new reception units being established.

In 2023, a larger number of unaccompanied minors entered the country, which resulted in more special units for minors while units for adults were closed. However, the total number of reception centres remained the same as in 2022.

On 31 December 2023, the reception system covered 35,579 persons and 112 reception units (90 units for adults, 22 special units for minors and 2 detention units). Situation 31 December 2022: 43,513 persons and 112 reception units (103 for adults and families, 9 for unaccompanied minors).

[The image shows a busy indoor space that appears to be a reception or activity area for children. There are numerous children of various ages engaged in play activities on a colorful carpet. Toys and play equipment are scattered around. Some adults in orange safety vests are visible, likely supervising the children. The room has large windows and appears bright and welcoming. This scene likely represents a reception center for asylum seekers, particularly catering to families with children.]

The chunk focuses on the reception of asylum seekers in Finland, highlighting adjustments in reception capacity due to increased demand, particularly following the war in Ukraine. As of December 31, 2023, the reception system accommodated 35,579 individuals across 112 units, including 90 for adults and 22 special units for unaccompanied minors, reflecting a decrease from 43,513 individuals in 2022. This information aligns with the document's broader theme of immigration statistics and trends in Finland for 2023.

metadata.parsed_text_markdown:
# Trafficking in human beings

## Residence permits issued to victims of trafficking in human beings

A first residence permit for a victim of human trafficking was issued to 57 persons in 2023 (2022: 8), a significant uptick from the previous year. A fixed-term residence permit (extended permit) on the same grounds was issued to 25 persons (2022: 20).

The number of cases involving indications of trafficking in human beings is substantially higher. Some of them have been granted international protection or a residence permit on other grounds, or the conditions for a residence permit have not been met. There are no reliable statistics available on cases involving suspected trafficking in human beings, as it does not constitute the primary grounds for the residence permit.

### First residence permits issued, victims of trafficking in human beings

| Year | Number of permits |
|------|-------------------|
| 2019 | 9                 |
| 2020 | 4                 |
| 2021 | 14                |
| 2022 | 8                 |
| 2023 | 57                |

Source: Finnish Immigration Service

### Gender distribution, first residence permits issued 2023

| Gender | Percentage |
|--------|------------|
| Men    | 63%        |
| Women  | 37%        |

__data__.text:
The chunk focuses on the issuance of residence permits to victims of trafficking in human beings in Finland, highlighting a significant increase from 8 permits in 2022 to 57 in 2023. It notes that while the number of cases indicating trafficking is higher, reliable statistics are lacking, as many cases do not meet the primary grounds for residence permits. Additionally, in 2023, 63% of the permits issued were to men, reflecting broader trends in immigration and asylum statistics presented throughout the document.

metadata.parsed_text_markdown:
# Assistance System for Victims of Human Trafficking

The Assistance System for Victims of Human Trafficking operates as part of the Joutseno reception centre. The Assistance System maintains statistics on persons who have sought inclusion in the system and who have been admitted to the system. At the end of 2023, the Assistance System for Victims of Human Trafficking included 1,563 people. The number of new clients admitted to the Assistance System in 2023 was 326, slightly less than in the previous year (2022: 367).

## New clients in the Assistance System 2019-2023

| Year | Number of New Clients |
|------|------------------------|
| 2019 | 229                    |
| 2020 | 247                    |
| 2021 | 243                    |
| 2022 | 367                    |
| 2023 | 326                    |

## New clients in the Assistance System based on the category of victimisation, 2023

| Victimisation category | New clients |
|------------------------|-------------|
| Sexual exploitation    | 57          |
| Forced labour          | 205         |
| Forced marriage        | 50          |
| Forced criminal activity | 5         |
| Child soldier          | less than 5 |
| Other exploitation     | 8           |

## Gender distribution, new clients, 2023

| Gender | Percentage |
|--------|------------|
| Men    | 42%        |
| Women  | 58%        |

Source: Joutseno reception centre, Assistance System for Victims of Human Trafficking

__data__.text:
The Assistance System for Victims of Human Trafficking, part of the Joutseno reception centre, reported a total of 1,563 individuals included in the system by the end of 2023, with 326 new clients admitted that year, a slight decrease from 367 in 2022. The majority of new clients in 2023 were victims of forced labour (205), followed by sexual exploitation (57) and forced marriage (50). This information highlights the ongoing challenges of human trafficking in Finland, aligning with the document's broader focus on immigration and asylum issues, including the protection of vulnerable populations.

# Citizenship

In 2023, a total of 13,077 persons acquired Finnish citizenship, a considerable increase compared to the previous year. The number of citizenship applications and declarations received was 19,809, a significant uptick from 2022 (14,093). The total number of negative decisions was 1,377. Negative decisions were most often due to insufficient proficiency in Finnish or Swedish, as has usually been the case in the previous years.

## Citizenship applications, citizenship declarations and persons granted Finnish citizenship, 2019-2023

| Year | Citizenship applications and declarations | Negative decisions | Persons granted Finnish citizenship |
|------|-------------------------------------------|--------------------|------------------------------------|
| 2019 | 13,052                                    | 1,482              | 10,086                              |
| 2020 | 13,380                                    | 1,211              | 8,759                               |
| 2021 | 16,274                                    | 889                | 7,596                               |
| 2022 | 14,093                                    | 1,142              | 10,479                              |
| 2023 | 19,809                                    | 1,377              | 13,077                              |

## Citizenship applications, top 5 nationalities, 2023

| Country     | Number of Applications |
|-------------|------------------------|
| Russia      | 2,487                  |
| Iraq        | 2,403                  |
| Syria       | 1,439                  |
| Afghanistan | 1,251                  |
| Somalia     | 1,089                  |

__data__.text:
The chunk focuses on the acquisition of Finnish citizenship in 2023, highlighting that 13,077 individuals obtained citizenship, marking a significant increase from the previous year. It notes a total of 19,809 citizenship applications and declarations, up from 14,093 in 2022, with 1,377 negative decisions primarily due to insufficient language proficiency. This information is part of a broader statistical review on immigration trends in Finland for 2023, which includes various aspects of migration, residence permits, and asylum processes.

metadata.parsed_text_markdown:
# Irregular migration

## Persons found to reside in the country illegally

In the migration glossary produced by the EMN network, the EMN Glossary, the Finnish translation of "irregular migration" means "immigration against the regulations". Among the Finnish authorities, the more common terms are "illegal entry" and "illegal stay".

The statistics shown below include — in accordance with the Eurostat criteria on illegal stay — persons found staying or working in without a valid permit either inland or at the external borders as well as persons who have been found to reside irregularly without valid documents before applying for asylum in Finland. Most of the irregular migrants included in the statistics only stay in the country for a short period. An example of this is persons who are at an external border of Finland leaving the Schengen area.

### Irregular migrants, top 5 nationalities, 2023
(excluding persons working without a work permit)

| Country | Number |
|---------|--------|
| Russia  | 219    |
| Iraq    | 89     |
| Somalia | 68     |
| China   | 60     |
| Turkey  | 53     |

Source: National Bureau of Investigation

__data__.text:
The section on irregular migration addresses the issue of individuals residing illegally in Finland, defining "irregular migration" as immigration against regulations, and highlighting the top nationalities of irregular migrants in 2023. It provides specific figures, noting that 219 individuals from Russia and 89 from Iraq were among the most common nationalities found to be residing illegally, contributing to the broader statistical analysis of immigration trends in Finland for 2023. This information aligns with the document's overall focus on immigration statistics and trends, including various categories of migration and asylum.

# Violations of entry ban

Criminal activity is often the cause for imposing a prohibition of entry (entry ban), which is evident in the group who are violating the prohibition of entry as well. As such, these figures reflect international itinerant crime.

| Third-country nationals detected violating an entry ban, top 5 nationalities, 2023 |    |
|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---:|
| Belarus                                                                        | 26 |
| Gambia                                                                         | 18 |
| Stateless                                                                      |  9 |
| Not known                                                                      |  5 |
| Algeria                                                                        |  4 |

Source: National Bureau of Investigation

# Irregular employment

Irregular employment is part of the informal economy, which is partly connected to irregular stay. For most irregular migrants, undeclared employment is the most convenient means of livelihood, but the international supply of cheap labour and undeclared workers is also growing.

The use of undeclared workers distorts competition: the supply of undeclared workers and cheap labour also involves organised crime, for which crime within corporate structures is a growing source of income.

Not nearly all of the persons who work illegally are staying irregularly in the country. The following statistics include persons working without any work permit regardless of whether they were staying in the country legally or not.

| Third-country nationals working without a work permit, top 5 nationalities, 2023 |    |
|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---:|
| Iraq                                                                           | 35 |
| Russia                                                                         | 22 |
| Nigeria                                                                        | 20 |
| Ukraine                                                                        | 17 |
| Kyrgyzstan                                                                     | 15 |

Source: National Bureau of Investigation

__data__.text:
The chunk addresses violations of entry bans and irregular employment among third-country nationals in Finland, highlighting the connection between criminal activity and immigration issues. In 2023, the top nationalities detected violating entry bans included Belarus (26 cases) and Gambia (18 cases), while the leading nationalities for irregular employment were Iraq (35 cases) and Russia (22 cases). This information aligns with the document's broader focus on immigration statistics and trends in Finland, particularly regarding enforcement and the informal economy.

metadata.parsed_text_markdown:
# Removal decisions and entry bans

## Decisions on refusal of entry

Decisions on refusal of entry may be made directly at the external border (returning) when the person does not meet the entry requirements or within the country on the grounds stipulated in the Aliens Act. The Police and border control authorities may decide on refusal of entry within three months of the alien's entry into the country. After that period, the Police or border control authorities must submit a proposal to the Finnish Immigration Service to the effect that the alien be refused entry or deported.

## Refusal of entry decisions

| Year | Finnish Immigration Service | Police | Finnish Border Guard |
|------|---------------------------|--------|----------------------|
| 2019 | 5,880                     | 754    | 1,489                |
| 2020 | 4,705                     | 451    | 2,441                |
| 2021 | 2,437                     | 236    | 3,181                |
| 2022 | 2,790                     | 328    | 4,192                |
| 2023 | 2,994                     | 555    | 2,168                |

Source: Finnish Immigration Service, Police, Finnish Border Guard

It presents statistics on refusal of entry decisions from 2019 to 2023, showing a general decline in such decisions over the years, with 2,994 refusals recorded in 2023. This information is part of a broader analysis of immigration and asylum processes in Finland, highlighting enforcement measures related to entry regulations.

The Finnish Immigration Service, the Police and Finnish Border Guard issue an entry ban on a person usually in connection with decisions on refusal of entry and deportation. The cases may include circumvention of the rules on entry or involvement in crime (among others, drug and property crimes).

Source: Finnish Immigration Service, Police, Finnish Border Guard

metadata.parsed_text_markdown:
# Deportation cases and decisions

When a foreign national has, or has had, a residence permit (the right of residence of an EU citizen has been registered / the EU citizen's family member has a residence card), and a decision is made to remove him/her from the country, he/she is subject to deportation. In 2023, a total of 1,511 deportation cases were opened in Finland and 1,638 deportation proposals were made.

A deportation decision was made on 1,197 cases. The most common grounds for deportation in 2023 were that a new temporary residence permit could not be issued for the person or the previous permit had been revoked. The reasons for not issuing a permit or for revoking it included, for example, circumvention of the rules on entry or insufficient subsistence. Criminal grounds were the reason in 135 deportation cases (approx. 11%).

## Deportation cases and decisions

| Year | Deportation cases | Deportation | No deportation |

| 2022 | 1,777             | 1,244       | 494            |
| 2021 | 1,936             | 1,302       | 602            |
| 2020 | 2,369             | 1,799       | 547            |
| 2019 | 2,507             | 1,963       | 544            |

Source: Finnish Immigration Service

metadata.parsed_text_markdown:
# Enforcement of removal from the country

In 2023, the Police removed a total of 2,123 persons from the country (2022: 1,740), of whom 372 were removed escorted (2022: 285). These figures have again been increasing from recent years, when there was a slight decrease partly attributable to challenges related to returns arising from the COVID-19 pandemic. The year 2016 was statistically record-breaking (6,657) due to the number of removals from the country of persons who had received negative decisions on their asylum applications. However, in general, the trend has been declining. The trend has correlated with the decrease in the number of asylum seekers.

## Persons removed from the country, top 5 nationalities

| Nationality       | Number of Persons |
|-------------------|-------------------|
| Russian Federation| 360               |
| Estonia           | 338               |
| Romania           | 190               |
| Iraq              | 116               |
| Belarus           | 102               |

Source: The Police

metadata.parsed_text_markdown:
# Voluntary return

A total of 181 persons were voluntarily repatriated in 2023, representing a slight increase from 2022 (130) and a change to the declining trend.

Finland has had project-based voluntary return programmes in place since 2010. The programmes have been co-funded by the EU Return Fund. The practical implementation has been carried out by the International Organization for Migration, IOM, which continues as the service provider for arranging the returns.

## Assisted voluntary return

| Year | Applications | Returns |
|------|-------------|---------|
| 2019 | 463         | 391     |
| 2020 | 317         | 217     |
| 2021 | 210         | 148     |
| 2022 | 147         | 130     |
| 2023 | 232         | 181     |

Source: International Organization for Migration IOM (the Helsinki office), vapaaehtoinenpaluu.fi
